## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 904, 292]]<|/det|>
9709/52  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 301, 338, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Probability & Statistics 1

You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 880, 636]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 664, 212, 678]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 681, 728, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 450, 91]]<|/det|>
1 Jacob throws three coins at the same time.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 87, 808, 108]]<|/det|>
The first coin is biased so that the probability of obtaining a head when it is thrown is \(\frac{1}{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 106, 828, 128]]<|/det|>
The second coin is biased so that the probability of obtaining a head when it is thrown is \(\frac{1}{4}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 127, 808, 149]]<|/det|>
The third coin is biased so that the probability of obtaining a head when it is thrown is \(\frac{1}{5}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 145, 556, 163]]<|/det|>
The random variable \(X\) is the number of heads obtained.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 177, 144, 194]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 173, 363, 195]]<|/det|>
(a) Show that \(\mathrm{P}(X=2)=\frac{3}{20}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 485, 144, 502]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 483, 534, 502]]<|/det|>
(b) Draw up the probability distribution table for \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
2 Last year, an online store sold a large number of computers. \(55 \%\) of the computers were made by company \(F\), \(30 \%\) were made by company \(G\) and \(15 \%\) were made by company \(H\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 120, 804, 138]]<|/det|>
A random sample of 3 customers who each bought a computer from this store is chosen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 153, 144, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 152, 878, 170]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the probability that the 3 customers bought computers all made by different companies.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 429, 814, 447]]<|/det|>
<pre>A random sample of 12 customers who each bought a computer from this store is chosen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 462, 144, 478]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 459, 918, 477]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the probability that fewer than 10 of these customers bought a computer made by company \(F\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 823, 91]]<|/det|>
<pre>A random sample of 140 customers who each bought a computer from this store is chosen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 106, 144, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 104, 918, 138]]<|/det|>
(c) Use a suitable approximation to find the probability that more than 24 of these customers bought a computer made by company \(H\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|> 3 The lengths of 250 leaves of a certain type of plant are measured, correct to the nearest centimetre. The results are summarised in the table below. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 120, 850, 173]]<|/det|>
Length (cm)5 - 910 - 1415 - 1920 - 2425 - 2930 - 39
Frequency182860724824
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 202, 144, 218]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 201, 809, 217]]<|/det|> (a) On the grid below, draw a cumulative frequency graph to illustrate this information. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[256, 228, 742, 705]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 527, 91]]<|/det|>
(b) \(38 \%\) of these leaves are of length \(k \mathrm{~cm}\) or more.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 106, 470, 123]]<|/det|>
Use your graph to find an estimate for \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 260, 144, 277]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 259, 640, 277]]<|/det|>
(c) Calculate an estimate for the mean length of these 250 leaves.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
4 Eddie has 16 toy cars, of which 8 are white, 5 are black and 3 are silver. He places all the cars in a bag and selects three of them at random, without replacement.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 121, 144, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 121, 611, 138]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the probability that all three cars are the same colour.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 918, 104]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the probability that, when the 3 cars are selected, at least one car is white and at least one car is black.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
5 The mass of peaches sold per day in a supermarket is normally distributed with mean 65.8 kg and standard deviation 9.6 kg .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 121, 144, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 120, 918, 138]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the probability that the mass of peaches sold on any given day is between 56 kg and 75 kg .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 75, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
<pre>The mass of cherries sold per day in a supermarket is normally distributed with mean 72.4 kg and standard deviation \(\sigma \mathrm{kg}\). It is known that on \(10 \%\) of days less than 59.1 kg of cherries are sold.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 121, 144, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 121, 314, 138]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the value of \(\sigma\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 490, 432, 507]]<|/det|>
<pre>The supermarket is open 7 days a week.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 522, 144, 539]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 521, 918, 554]]<|/det|>
(c) Find the probability that, in a randomly chosen week, the first day on which less than 59.1 kg of cherries are sold is the fifth day of the week.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 660, 144, 677]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 660, 918, 693]]<|/det|>
(d) Find the probability that, in a randomly chosen week, the first day on which less than 59.1 kg of cherries are sold is before the fifth day of the week.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 918, 121]]<|/det|>
6 Alissa has 10 different books from the series Squares and Circles. The books look similar except for their colour. There are 3 blue books, 2 red books, 2 yellow books, 1 orange book, 1 purple book and 1 green book.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 135, 908, 152]]<|/det|>
Alissa places the books in a row on her shelf. She is only interested in the arrangement of the colours.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 167, 144, 184]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 166, 686, 183]]<|/det|>
(a) How many different colour arrangements are there of the 10 books?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 445, 144, 462]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 444, 918, 476]]<|/det|>
(b) How many different colour arrangements are there of the 10 books in which the 3 blue books are together, but the 2 yellow books are not next to each other?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
(c) How many different colour arrangements are there of the 10 books with exactly 4 books between the 2 yellow books?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 429, 794, 446]]<|/det|>
<pre>Alissa selects 4 books from her 10 different books from the series Squares and Circles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 462, 144, 478]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 460, 918, 492]]<|/det|>
(d) Find the number of different selections if the 4 books include at least 1 red book, at most 1 blue book and exactly 1 yellow book.

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 72, 567, 88]]<|/det|>
# Additional page  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 102, 918, 135]]<|/det|>
If you use the following page to complete the answer to any question, the question number must be clearly shown.
